text: The Zettelkasten Method is a personal knowledge management system developed by German sociologist Niklas Luhmann in the mid-20th century.
Niklas Luhmann published more than 70 books and nearly 400 scholarly articles on subjects including sociology, philosophy, law, economics, politics, art, religion, ecology, and mass media.
Luhmann attributed his extraordinary academic productivity directly to his 'slip-box' or Zettelkasten system, which allowed him to develop ideas over decades.
The core principle of the Zettelkasten method is creating atomic notes, each containing exactly one self-contained idea that can be understood independently.
In the Zettelkasten system, atomic notes are deliberately connected through explicit links to form an emergent non-hierarchical network of knowledge that can be traversed in multiple dimensions.
